tabs.header_iregular:
Alright, let's see what to use over-the-counter for this dry mouth.


You will need saliva substitutes to help with this dry mouth.

Bear in mind that this is a temporary fix. The best way to take care of this is getting rid of the cause of dryness of the mouth.

With this in mind, see what we recommend for dry mouth over-the-counter

collapsable.title: xylitol click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Look for formulations with xylitol which is a tooth-friendly sugar alcohol. 

It has advantages of reducing cavities, remineralization of the enamel before cavities are formed and the sensation of sweetness increases secretion of saliva. 

Examples: Biotene, Oasis, ACT

collapsable.title: Carboxymethylcellulose click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Look for formulations of mouthwashes with carboxymethyl cellulose or hydroxyethyl cellulose.

The viscosity simulates saliva.

Examples: Biotene, Oasis

collapsable.title: Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
1. Regularly sip water.
2. Chew sugar-free gums or suck on sugar-free hard candies.
3. Stay away from over-the-counter antihistamines
4. Do not breathe through the mouth. 
5. Cut down on the intake of coffee or energy drinks. They contain caffeine which can cause dry mouth.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/01/2016 at 10:49:pm

tabs.header:
What if you are currently experiencing any of the conditions listed below?

Or if you have a question for the pharmacist?

collapsable.title: You have a question click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Please contact the pharmacist. He or she will gladly answer your questions.

collapsable.title: Contacting the pharmacist click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You may have to unlock the contact form using social networking tools (facebook, twitter, google+, linkedIn) we have made available to you.

If you can't do this, you will have to wait a few seconds depending on the number of users at the time.

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answered and not stored in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authored. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

tabs.header:
Article currently being updated and reviewed by the pharmacist.
Please check back later.

tabs.header_iregular:
Stuffy nose? Let's take care of this.

This will assume you are only looking at a stuffy nose for one reason or another.

The approach would be to thin the mucus, reduce the inflammation and shrink the swollen blood vessels.

With this in mind, see what I recommend below.

collapsable.title: Saline wash click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Always better to start with a saline wash before using medications.

Medications for stuffy nose comes with some baggage. They will either bump up the blood pressure, make you wired, deny you sleep, make you jittery or even cause stuffy nose if you use it for too long.

collapsable.title: Neti-Pot click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
A good idea if you want to avoid using decongestant medications as much as possible.

The only problem is, you either like it or you don't. To like it, use it with Alkalol® a saline rinse formulated with natural extracts and essential oils  for an invigorating clean.

Once you get past the initial feeling of accidentally inhaling water while swimming, you will love using it.

collapsable.title: Decongestants click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Nasal sprays

Start with the decongestant nasal spray. These start to work within 10 minutes.

You can then switch to decongestant tablets or syrup if still congested after 3 or 4 days.

At about 3 to 5 days, you must stop using the nasal spray if you still have a stuffy nose. That is when you will start experiencing the rebound effect of the nasal spray making you congested instead of providing relief (rebound effect).

 

Prefer nasal spray with oxymetazoline for 12-hour dosing.

Those with phenylephrine require more frequent use of 4 to 6 hours.
 

Pills:

Ask for pseudoephedrine at the pharmacy counter.

You will need a government issued ID to monitor your daily or monthly quantity limit.

Do not use phenylephrine found in the cold aisle.    

The strength approved by the FDA for nasal congestion is not effective and using a higher dose will cause more side effects and won't work either. Stay away from that.

collapsable.title: Nasal spray steroids click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Steroidal nasal sprays can reduce the inflammation that is causing the nasal congestion.

But you have to give it about 7 days to kick in.

If you get nasal congestion often as in allergy situations or nasal polyps, you will need to invest in this. Both for prevention and relief purposes.

Do not get this if your stuffy nose is due to a cold. It won't work.

collapsable.title: Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content: 1. Invest in a humidifier.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/02/2016 at 04:35:pm

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's take care of this runny nose.

This will assume you are only looking at a runny nose for reasons other than a cold, flu or allergy situations.

With this in mind, see what I recommend for runny nose below.

collapsable.title: Antihistamine click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
If the runny nose is caused by histamine 

release as in allergy situations, an antihistamine should take care of it by blocking histamine getting to the cells.

There are two types of antihistamines used for a runny nose, first generation (diphenhydramine, chlorpheniramine) and second generation (loratadine, cetirizine, fexofenadine). The main difference is the side effect of drowsiness caused by first-generation antihistamines.

If the runny nose is caused by a cold, stick with the first generation antihistamines. The second generation like loratadine, cetirizine or fexofenadine do not work for cold symptoms.

collapsable.title: Saline rinse click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
There are different types. 

The spray is basically to moisturize the nasal passages. The rinse is used to thin the mucus that lines the passages so you can gently blow it out.

For a runny nose, you will use the rinse. Neti-pot is good if you are used to it, but for a quick job, get a sinus rinse with packets. Be sure to always use distilled water.

We recommend you include Alkalol® for a soothing effect.

collapsable.title: Steroidal nasal spray click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
If you already have a runny nose, 

this is not going to work. They need a few days to kick in. Average 5 days. So don't waste your money if you have not been using a steroidal nasal spray and currently have a runny nose.

If you are prone to a runny nose as in allergy, this has to be a part of your treatment regimen. Daily use will be great for about 4 to 6 months a year.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/02/2016 at 07:04:pm
